measured_by: two-slider boundary task marking the range of ‘reasonable’ opinions on a 1–7 attitude scale
justification: “The ‘cognitive’ latitude … was defined as the ‘range of opinions that you think are reasonable for a person to hold.’ … Participants … used two sliders to mark the ‘boundaries’ of the range of opinions that they thought were reasonable for each issue.”

measured_by: two-slider boundary task marking the range of opinions that ‘don’t bother you or make you angry’ on a 1–7 attitude scale
justification: “The ‘affective’ latitude … was defined as the ‘range of opinions that DON’T bother you or make you angry.’ Participants … used sliders to mark the boundaries of the range of opinions that did not bother them or make them angry.”

measured_by: item-by-item yes/no judgments of whether specific individuals’ opinions are ‘reasonable’ (count of accepted positions)
justification: “For each trial, participants made … a cognitive judgment: they indicated whether or not they thought the person’s opinion was reasonable (yes/no) … Contextualized latitude measures were computed as count variables … based on participants’ responses to these opinions.”

measured_by: item-by-item inside/outside judgments of whether specific individuals’ opinions ‘bother’ them (count of positions not bothering)
justification: “Participants … indicated whether the opinion was inside or outside of their latitude of acceptance (‘inside = does not bother me or make me angry’ or ‘outside = bothers me or makes me angry’).”

measured_by: hypothetical math-partner selection scenario (choosing between better-math/different-opinion vs worse-math/same-opinion partner)
justification: “Participants were asked to think about choosing a partner for a ‘difficult math task’ … After reading about the partners, participants … were asked to select which partner they would ‘choose to be…[their] partner.’”
construct: willingness to associate with another person
